library (ggcharts)

title: HW8
text:
Reading and validating data
Reading CSV file

bike_rentals <- read_csv("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/~online/datasets/SeoulBikeData.csv", 
                              locale = locale(encoding = "latin1"),
                         name_repair = function(nm) str_to_lower(str_replace_all(str_replace_all(nm, " ", "_"), "[()/°%]", "")))

Rows: 8760 Columns: 14
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (4): date, seasons, holiday, functioning_day
dbl (10): rented_bike_count, hour, temperaturec, humidity, wind_speed_ms, vi...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

bike_rentals

# A tibble: 8,760 × 14
   date       rented_bike_count  hour temperaturec humidity wind_speed_ms
   <chr>                  <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>    <dbl>         <dbl>
 1 01/12/2017               254     0         -5.2       37           2.2
 2 01/12/2017               204     1         -5.5       38           0.8
 3 01/12/2017               173     2         -6         39           1  
 4 01/12/2017               107     3         -6.2       40           0.9
 5 01/12/2017                78     4         -6         36           2.3
 6 01/12/2017               100     5         -6.4       37           1.5
 7 01/12/2017               181     6         -6.6       35           1.3
 8 01/12/2017               460     7         -7.4       38           0.9
 9 01/12/2017               930     8         -7.6       37           1.1
10 01/12/2017               490     9         -6.5       27           0.5
# ℹ 8,750 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: visibility_10m <dbl>, dew_point_temperaturec <dbl>,
#   solar_radiation_mjm2 <dbl>, rainfallmm <dbl>, snowfall_cm <dbl>,
#   seasons <chr>, holiday <chr>, functioning_day <chr>


Renaming variables for easy use

bike_rentals <- bike_rentals |>
  rename("temp" = "temperaturec",
         "wind_speed" = "wind_speed_ms",
         "visibility" = `visibility_10m`,
         "dew_point_temp" = "dew_point_temperaturec",
         "rainfall" = "rainfallmm",
         "solar_radiation" = "solar_radiation_mjm2",
         "snowfall" = "snowfall_cm")

Validating numeric data

psych::describe(bike_rentals)

                  vars    n    mean     sd  median trimmed    mad   min     max
date*                1 8760  183.00 105.37  183.00  183.00 134.92   1.0  365.00
rented_bike_count    2 8760  704.60 645.00  504.50  612.58 553.75   0.0 3556.00
hour                 3 8760   11.50   6.92   11.50   11.50   8.90   0.0   23.00
temp                 4 8760   12.88  11.94   13.70   13.19  13.94 -17.8   39.40
humidity             5 8760   58.23  20.36   57.00   58.02  23.72   0.0   98.00
wind_speed           6 8760    1.72   1.04    1.50    1.63   1.04   0.0    7.40
visibility           7 8760 1436.83 608.30 1698.00 1509.50 447.75  27.0 2000.00
dew_point_temp       8 8760    4.07  13.06    5.10    4.76  14.38 -30.6   27.20
solar_radiation      9 8760    0.57   0.87    0.01    0.38   0.01   0.0    3.52
rainfall            10 8760    0.15   1.13    0.00    0.00   0.00   0.0   35.00
snowfall            11 8760    0.08   0.44    0.00    0.00   0.00   0.0    8.80
seasons*            12 8760    2.50   1.11    2.00    2.49   1.48   1.0    4.00
holiday*            13 8760    1.95   0.22    2.00    2.00   0.00   1.0    2.00
functioning_day*    14 8760    1.97   0.18    2.00    2.00   0.00   1.0    2.00
                    range  skew kurtosis   se
date*              364.00  0.00    -1.20 1.13
rented_bike_count 3556.00  1.15     0.85 6.89
hour                23.00  0.00    -1.20 0.07
temp                57.20 -0.20    -0.84 0.13
humidity            98.00  0.06    -0.80 0.22
wind_speed           7.40  0.89     0.73 0.01
visibility        1973.00 -0.70    -0.96 6.50
dew_point_temp      57.80 -0.37    -0.76 0.14
solar_radiation      3.52  1.50     1.12 0.01
rainfall            35.00 14.53   284.76 0.01
snowfall             8.80  8.44    93.73 0.00
seasons*             3.00  0.00    -1.35 0.01
holiday*             1.00 -4.16    15.33 0.00
functioning_day*     1.00 -5.17    24.72 0.00


From the above psych::describe, there are no missing data in any of the columns with summary looks proper.
Checking missing values for each column

sapply (bike_rentals, function (x)sum (is.na(x)))

             date rented_bike_count              hour              temp 
                0                 0                 0                 0 
         humidity        wind_speed        visibility    dew_point_temp 
                0                 0                 0                 0 
  solar_radiation          rainfall          snowfall           seasons 
                0                 0                 0                 0 
          holiday   functioning_day 
                0                 0 


Checking unique values for the categorical variables

unique(bike_rentals$seasons)

[1] "Winter" "Spring" "Summer" "Autumn"

unique(bike_rentals$holiday)

[1] "No Holiday" "Holiday"   

unique(bike_rentals$functioning_day)

[1] "Yes" "No" 


Creating factors of the categorical variables

bike_rentals <- bike_rentals |>
  mutate(date = dmy(date),
         seasons = as.factor(seasons),
         holiday = as.factor(holiday),
         functioning_day = as.factor(functioning_day)
        )
bike_rentals

# A tibble: 8,760 × 14
   date       rented_bike_count  hour  temp humidity wind_speed visibility
   <date>                 <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>
 1 2017-12-01               254     0  -5.2       37        2.2       2000
 2 2017-12-01               204     1  -5.5       38        0.8       2000
 3 2017-12-01               173     2  -6         39        1         2000
 4 2017-12-01               107     3  -6.2       40        0.9       2000
 5 2017-12-01                78     4  -6         36        2.3       2000
 6 2017-12-01               100     5  -6.4       37        1.5       2000
 7 2017-12-01               181     6  -6.6       35        1.3       2000
 8 2017-12-01               460     7  -7.4       38        0.9       2000
 9 2017-12-01               930     8  -7.6       37        1.1       2000
10 2017-12-01               490     9  -6.5       27        0.5       1928
# ℹ 8,750 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: dew_point_temp <dbl>, solar_radiation <dbl>,
#   rainfall <dbl>, snowfall <dbl>, seasons <fct>, holiday <fct>,
#   functioning_day <fct>


Subsetting on functioning_day = Yes as summary on the rented bike count is all 0

bike_rentals |>
  filter(functioning_day == "No") |>
  group_by(date, seasons, holiday, functioning_day) |>
  summarize(across(rented_bike_count, 
                   list("mean" = mean, "median" = median, "sd" = sd ),
                   .names = "{.fn}_{.col}"))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'date', 'seasons', 'holiday'. You can
override using the `.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 13 × 7
# Groups:   date, seasons, holiday [13]
   date       seasons holiday    functioning_day mean_rented_bike_count
   <date>     <fct>   <fct>      <fct>                            <dbl>
 1 2018-04-11 Spring  No Holiday No                                   0
 2 2018-05-10 Spring  No Holiday No                                   0
 3 2018-09-18 Autumn  No Holiday No                                   0
 4 2018-09-19 Autumn  No Holiday No                                   0
 5 2018-09-28 Autumn  No Holiday No                                   0
 6 2018-09-30 Autumn  No Holiday No                                   0
 7 2018-10-02 Autumn  No Holiday No                                   0
 8 2018-10-04 Autumn  No Holiday No                                   0
 9 2018-10-06 Autumn  No Holiday No                                   0
10 2018-10-09 Autumn  Holiday    No                                   0
11 2018-11-03 Autumn  No Holiday No                                   0
12 2018-11-06 Autumn  No Holiday No                                   0
13 2018-11-09 Autumn  No Holiday No                                   0
# ℹ 2 more variables: median_rented_bike_count <dbl>,
#   sd_rented_bike_count <dbl>


Calculating sum across rented_bike_count, rainfall and snowfall variables and mean across the weather variables for final model data sets

bike_model_data <- bike_rentals |>
  filter(functioning_day == "Yes") |>
  group_by(date, seasons, holiday) |>
  summarize(across(c(rented_bike_count, rainfall, snowfall, temp, humidity, wind_speed, visibility,
                     dew_point_temp, solar_radiation),
                   .fns = list("total" = sum, "mean" = mean),
                   .names = "{.fn}_{.col}")) |>
  select(date, seasons, holiday, total_rented_bike_count, total_rainfall, total_snowfall, mean_temp, mean_humidity, mean_wind_speed,
         mean_visibility, mean_dew_point_temp, mean_solar_radiation)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'date', 'seasons'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.

bike_model_data

# A tibble: 353 × 12
# Groups:   date, seasons [353]
   date       seasons holiday    total_rented_bike_count total_rainfall
   <date>     <fct>   <fct>                        <dbl>          <dbl>
 1 2017-12-01 Winter  No Holiday                    9539            0  
 2 2017-12-02 Winter  No Holiday                    8523            0  
 3 2017-12-03 Winter  No Holiday                    7222            4  
 4 2017-12-04 Winter  No Holiday                    8729            0.1
 5 2017-12-05 Winter  No Holiday                    8307            0  
 6 2017-12-06 Winter  No Holiday                    6669            1.3
 7 2017-12-07 Winter  No Holiday                    8549            0  
 8 2017-12-08 Winter  No Holiday                    8032            0  
 9 2017-12-09 Winter  No Holiday                    7233            0  
10 2017-12-10 Winter  No Holiday                    3453            4.1
# ℹ 343 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: total_snowfall <dbl>, mean_temp <dbl>,
#   mean_humidity <dbl>, mean_wind_speed <dbl>, mean_visibility <dbl>,
#   mean_dew_point_temp <dbl>, mean_solar_radiation <dbl>

title: HW8
text:
Summary plots
Creating box plots for total bike rental with categorical variables

ggplot(data = bike_model_data,
      aes(x = seasons, y = total_rented_bike_count, fill = seasons)) + 
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, alpha = 0.4)








From the above box plot , we can say that season direct influence on the bike rental count with winter being the slow season and summer being the high season.

ggplot(data = bike_model_data,
      aes(x = holiday, y = total_rented_bike_count, fill = holiday)) + 
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, alpha = 0.4)








The above box plot shows that there are less outliers for bike rented during non holidays than holidays.
Creating scatter plots for numerical variables

ggplot(data = bike_model_data,
      aes(x = total_rainfall, y = total_rented_bike_count, color = holiday)) +
  geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = lm)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









The above scatter plot shows that there is high correlation between rainfall amount and bike rented count. Also the rental count is affected by holiday as well.

ggplot(data = bike_model_data,
      aes(x = total_rainfall, y = total_rented_bike_count, color = seasons)) +
  geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = lm)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









From the above line graph, apart of from rainfall, there is some correlation between the bike rental count and seasons as well.

ggplot(data = bike_model_data,
      aes(x = mean_temp, y = total_rented_bike_count, color = holiday)) +
  geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = lm)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









From the above graph, when the temp increases the bike rental count also increases, with temperature in the range 2o to 25 being more favorable. Also from the line fit on holiday shows that holiday has some effect in the total bike rent count.

ggplot(data = bike_model_data,
      aes(x = mean_temp, y = total_rented_bike_count, color = seasons)) +
  geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = lm)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









From the above graph, when the temp increases the bike rental count also increases, with temperature in the range 2o to 25 being more favorable. Apart from temperature, the season also affect the total bike rental count. As shown in graph in summer bike rental count increases than in winter.

title: HW8
HW8
text:
Fitting linear model
Set the linear regression engine to “lm”

MLR_spec <- linear_reg() |>
  set_engine("lm")

creating workflows for model

MLR_wkf1 <- workflow()|>
  add_recipe(recipe1) |>
  add_model(MLR_spec)

MLR_wkf2 <- workflow()|>
  add_recipe(recipe2) |>
  add_model(MLR_spec)

MLR_wkf3 <- workflow()|>
  add_recipe(recipe3) |>
  add_model(MLR_spec)

Fitting the models with the cross validation folds

MLR_fit1 <- MLR_wkf1 |>
  fit_resamples(bike_rentals_cv)

MLR_fit2 <- MLR_wkf2 |>
  fit_resamples(bike_rentals_cv)

→ A | warning: prediction from rank-deficient fit; consider predict(., rankdeficient="NA")


There were issues with some computations   A: x1
There were issues with some computations   A: x1




MLR_fit3 <- MLR_wkf3 |>
  fit_resamples(bike_rentals_cv)

→ A | warning: prediction from rank-deficient fit; consider predict(., rankdeficient="NA")


There were issues with some computations   A: x1
There were issues with some computations   A: x1





Collecting metrices from each of the fit

rbind(MLR_fit1 |> collect_metrics() |> filter(.metric == "rmse"),
      MLR_fit2 |> collect_metrics() |> filter(.metric == "rmse"),
      MLR_fit3 |> collect_metrics() |> filter(.metric == "rmse")) |> 
  mutate(Model = c("Model 1", "Model 2", "Model 3")) |>
  select(Model, mean, n, std_err)

# A tibble: 3 × 4
  Model    mean     n std_err
  <chr>   <dbl> <int>   <dbl>
1 Model 1 0.301    10  0.0170
2 Model 2 0.230    10  0.0208
3 Model 3 0.238    10  0.0205


From the above table, we can see that Model 2 has the the least rmse
Fitting the best model (model 2) to entire training set date,

MLR_wkf2 |>
  last_fit(bike_rentals_split) |>
  collect_metrics()

# A tibble: 2 × 4
  .metric .estimator .estimate .config        
  <chr>   <chr>          <dbl> <chr>          
1 rmse    standard       0.202 pre0_mod0_post0
2 rsq     standard       0.930 pre0_mod0_post0


fitting the final model

final_model <- MLR_wkf2 |>
  fit(bike_rentals_train)
tidy(final_model)

# A tibble: 21 × 5
   term                 estimate std.error statistic   p.value
   <chr>                   <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>
 1 (Intercept)            9.77      0.130      75.1  1.25e-169
 2 total_rainfall        -0.359     0.0258    -13.9  9.18e- 33
 3 total_snowfall        -0.0223    0.0146     -1.52 1.30e-  1
 4 mean_temp             -0.469     0.280      -1.68 9.49e-  2
 5 mean_humidity         -0.290     0.106      -2.73 6.86e-  3
 6 mean_wind_speed       -0.0384    0.0160     -2.40 1.71e-  2
 7 mean_visibility        0.0273    0.0211      1.30 1.95e-  1
 8 mean_dew_point_temp    0.893     0.324       2.75 6.35e-  3
 9 mean_solar_radiation   0.157     0.0251      6.25 1.82e-  9
10 seasons_Spring        -0.382     0.187      -2.04 4.22e-  2
# ℹ 11 more rows


extracting the final model fit in lm form

my_fit <- extract_fit_parsnip(final_model)
lm_fit <- my_fit$fit
summary(lm_fit)


Call:
stats::lm(formula = ..y ~ ., data = data)
